element_texts.text: Yellowstone National Park Notes compiled by Edith F Burt July 26th to 31st 1907 Read & pass on Return to Mrs H J Burt 2223 Williams

Notes Compiled 
After some consideration we decided to go through the Park by the way of the Wylie Permanent Camps in preference to the Transportation Co way, thinking the informality of the camps more to our liking than the hotels would be. The regular trip takes five & a half days but one can stay longer. I met Mr Burt at Livingston, Montana & we journeyed together to Gardiner, a distance of fifty-four miles through a beautiful country called Paradise Valley. At Gardiner we arrayed ourselves for the outing taking warm clothing but only as little as was necessary
File:Gardiner Railroad Station and Archway File:Yellowstone Park Gateway at Gardiner

File:Eagle Nest Rock Near Gardiner
It is amidst the rugged peaks
File:The Mammoth Hotel File:Jupiter Terrace at Mammoth Hot Springs File:Title, C. B. "Buffalo" One Mile From Mammoth Hot Springs

These beautiful formations are wonderfully colored and no artist can paint the shades they really have. So do not think pictures or post cards over-done. Terrace after terrace empties its clear hot contents out the one below, tinting & painting as it goes. What is referred to as "Hoodoo Land" is a wonderful region where once must have occurred a gigantic upheaval for boulders of incredible size & shape are strewn everywhere. They are of a grayish white & irregular of shape & truly ghostly looking

File:Golden Gate Cost - Concrete Bridge $10,000
Golden Gate as its name implies has rocky walls of a golden yellow color. The road built above the canyon through a solid mass of rock is one if the most wonderful feats of engineering.

File:Swan Lake (or Willow Park) Camp
File:Bear at Garbage Pile, Lake Camp
Our stay over night in this camp was novel, being the first. The tents are nice & clean with board floors, a small wood stove & most comfortable beds. The camp rules are on the boarding-school order. Lights out

at ten o'clock. We were all tired enough to obey. The rising bell rings at six, breakfast is at six-thirty & off on the drive at seven. We were awakened plenty early by a [din?] of cow bells when they drove into camp the horses & cows. It sounded like a [chivaree?]. Then he camp boy came to make our firs and bring in warm water. The meals are served family style and we all sat at one long table on benched. The food was good & we being always

hungry, ate heartily. This is really the starting place for the drive as the crowd is divided up, five riding in a wagon with a driver. The rig is a regular mountain surrey, good springs & exceedingly comfortable. Two horses are sufficient for the drives. The wagons keep fairly together & in regular order, so that when a stop is made we see more or less of the rest of the party. There were six rigs this day making thirty tourists with six "savages" as the drivers are called tho each has his own nickname

Artemesia Geyser. A little farther on a stop is made to view the lovely Morning Glory where, as Chittenden says, the quiescent pool is seen at its best. Just beyond the Morning Glory are the Fan and Mortar Geysers, while the Riverside is seen at the crossing of the Firehole. Next in order and just before turning into camp the remarkable craters of the Grotto and Giant are passed. Our new camp here is nicely situated in a beautiful grove of young pines, and is near to the Splendid, Daisy, Riverside, Grotto and Giant geysers. From our Observation Knoll at this camp one has the finest view obtainable of the Gayser Basin. 
File:Obsidian Cliff (Volcanic Glass)
File:Gibbon Canyon

The Gibbon Lunch Station is situated in a pretty place and we here got quite acquainted with our party. We made the acquaintance of a tame squirrel by the name of Rusty who ate from our hands and appeared real friendly. There were a great number of chipmunks & pine squirrels about the camp. Here we rested for an hour & a half before resuming our way.

File:Cascade of the Firehole River
File:The Fountain Hotel
This hotel was quite a distance from our camp so it was not visited, though we passed by. It is about a mile from the Fountain Geyser for which it is named. The geyser plays

every eight to twelve hours, so we did not see it in operation. Here also are the Mammoth Paint Pots which are continually boiling heavily like a pot of mush. They are all of light colors. white, grey, pink, rose, lavender & light green. The substance really looks of the consistency of paint. Some spattered me & when dried brushed off like clay.

File:Excelsior Geyser
Excelsior has not erupted for twenty years but boils furiously

and empties its water into the Firehole River. 
The picture on opposite page does not do justice to the Morning Glory Pool. It is not so yellow but more white at the edge & where the water is thin over the crystal formation, it is a light blue shading to the deepest of blues in the center where the opening really is. This was one of the most beautiful sights to me unless I except the Emerald Pool which is on the same order.

File:Grotto Geyser, Cone
The Grotto operates every three or four hours. I saw it twice. it gushes from the several openings

File:Castle and Beehive Geysers
In Operation it goes for about thirty minutes.

File:Castle Well, Castle Geyser
Castle erupts from eight to thirty hours (the book says) We saw it once however. The blue pool is known as its indicator

File:Mirrored Beauty of Majestic "Old Faithful" Continental Divide in the Distance
File:Old Faithful in Eruption
Goes about every 65 minutes

File:Old Faithful Inn
We reached the Upper Geyser Camp at 530 P. M. and rested until supper was served. After supper we walked up to the Old Faithful Inn to see the search light play on Old Faithful Geyser. We had ample time to go over the place before dark and found a most unique & beautiful building, perfectly appointed in all its rustic  elegance. In the center of the main room is an immense four

sided fire place built of stone. On one side is a queer looking clock. The whole building is of logs carefully selected for the places. The doors & attachments are all of the "barn door caste" When the time came we filed out to view the geyser. It gives some preliminary symptoms & then shoots for several minutes. With the search light on it & the rays focused so as to make the rainbow tints appear it is as real an electric fountain as we have all seen.

all seen. 
By the time we reached camp we were glad to retire. The ones who staid there had been enjoying a camp-fire and pop-corn. During the night I remember of hearing occasionally some old geyser roaring away for all he was worth. The next morning Sunday we were taken over the formations by a guide and had the interesting features pointed out. One geyser has a crater lengthwise along its Cone & shoots right across the Firehole river it is called the "Riverside"
File:The Punch Bowl a quiesent spring
The Crater of Oblong Geyser-" 6 hrs - 50 feet"

Here we saw the Emerald Pool, the most beautiful work of art you could imagine. I cannot describe it nor can I ever forget its shading rays of green. The handkerchief pool called the devils laundry is a queer place. Tourists throw in their handkerchiefs & they are drawn under by a current away down out of sight & come up after some little time boiled clean.

In the evening around the camp fire there was an interesting service. We had two ministers in our party & they were quite interesting. There was a small organ & I led the singing for the hymns just at the close a big thunder storm burst upon us & we just got into the tent as the rain poured down. At 700 AM we were up again ready to start to the Lake Camp. We had some fine brook trout for breakfast which one of our drivers had spent the afternoon in catching.

ride across the Lake. This steamer ride is included in the regular ticket. Yellowstone Lake is 7,741 feet, or nearly one and one-half miles, above the sea level. Its area is 140 sq. Miles; its waters are fresh, coming as they do from the snow drips of the Absarokas are icy cold, and transparent to great depths. The steamer ride is one of the most enjoyable features of our trip. Not only is it a welcome change from the coach riding but it is a novel experience to ride on a steamer at an elevation of a mile and a half above the sea, and then, too, the view from the Lake is unsurpassed. A landing is made at Dot Island where some fine buffalo, elk, antelope, and other animals native to the Park are seen. The tourist arrives at Lake Camp in time for fishing that evening. Fishing tackle, Lake Boat Co. at Landing. The fish here are mostly Salmon Trout though the Silver Trout are also found. 
At noon we arrived at lunch quite hungry & were again treated to fish. Salmon trout this time, not quite so good but plenty good enough. On the way over to the steamer we saw many interesting hot pools paint-pots etc. also the famous hot water cove in the Lake or Fishing Cove any way it is a pot of hot water set in the Lake. The picture is on the next page

the steamer trip was so enjoyable & we had a jolly good time. Before landing we engaged a boat guide & equipment for fishing as were assured that if we caught us fish would not have to pay. I must say here that Henry had fished several times unsuccessfully & he thot this the opportunity of his trip. $1.50 an hour, No fish-no pay." The boat ride out in to the river was ideal. There were fish, everybody caught some. I drew five fine looking ones

File:The Fishing Covet 
and they were hard to get in & I thot it quite enough though H. J. would have willingly gotten more than we did ? After a couple hours on the Lake we went in to supper to hear the fish stories. After awhile we walked down to the Lake Hotel to inspect it & to see the bears as they came up to the garbage pile for
File:Lake Steamer File:Lake Hotel File:The Lake

their food. We had seen a few at most of the camps but here we saw eleven in all and two black cubs as playful as kittens. They were up in the trees part of the time. When we got back to our camp there was the camp-fire singing, popping of corn & we always managed a lot of fun with it all. Everybody had a funny story to tell or some stunt to entertain with.

File:Mud Geyser File:Hayden Valley between Lake and Falls
In this valley thousands of deer & elk make their home, so they told us.
File:Great Falls of the Yellowstone, 360 feet
File:Upper Falls of the Yellowstone, 140 feet

File:The Canyon File:Cement Bridge over Yellowstone River
The canyon is the climax of the whole trip & if we could have spared the time would have staid over here as such sights can not be

absorbed in a few hours. We were taken up the canyon for three miles & then brot back to camp for lunch & left to spend the afternoon as we wished. The first sight of the Upper Falls is splendid & the roar is great, but after going on we do not return here. A short distance [?] brings the tourist to a bend in the road which at once unfolds to him the whole vista of the "Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone"

From Chittenden's Book on Yellowstone Park "The Grand Canon of the Yellowstone is acknowledged without parallel among the natural wonders of the globe. Other canons have greater depths & more imposing walls but there are none which in the words of Captain Ludlow, "unite more potently the two requisites of majesty & beauty" "It is the volcanic roack through which the river has cut its way that gives the Grand Canon its distinctive character. It is pre-eminently a canon of color. The hues

has no existence that cannot be found there "Hung up & let down & spread abroad are all the colors o the land, sea & sky" says [Jalurage?], without the hyperbole." "The Lower Fall of the river must be placed in the front rank of similar phenomena. It carries not one twentieth of the water of Niagara but Niagara is in no single part as beautiful. It's height is 310 feet. Its descent is very regular, slightly broken by a point of rock on the right bank. A third of the fall is

hidden behind the wast cloud of spray which forever conceals the mad play of the waters beneath but the mighty turmoil of that recess in the rocks may be judged from the deep-toned thunder which rises in ceaseless cadence & jars the air for miles around." Thomas Moran has a celebrated painting of the canon which now adorns the Capitol at Washington.

fishing. In the evening we spent an unusual time around the camp fire, singing and telling stories, some of them were specially good and appropriate. Next morning we started on the last stretch of our way. We felt that there could be little left for us to see now that we would appreciate. After passing Norris, our road is the same as we came in over & after driving twenty-five miles  we are again at Swan Lake Camp

in time for lunch. At 3:30 we again take the big coach for Gardiner and reach there in time for supper & to get out train. We reached Livingston about nine o'clock and got off and had refreshments before retiring as our sleeper remained in the yards until five in the morning. After breakfast Mr Burt left me at Logan to go on business to [Hamilton Mount?] and I wnet on to Butte to spend a day before going on to Salt Lake City. One day in Butte is quite enough & I was glad to go. I spent nearly a

week in Salk Lake visiting & then came on home alone, not waiting for Henry as had intended, though he followed me three days later. I was anxious about Jack and had heard very meagre reports from home, Since my return have been glad to rest for nearly a week almost unoccupied EFB

The Party 
Mr & Mrs Francis Murphy (copper mine owner) Central City Colo
Dr & Mrs Smith (retired) Pittsburg, Pa. 
Dr & Mrs Britton [(State entormologist)?] New Haven, Conn
Mr & Mrs Colby (sheep rancher) Great Falls, Mont
Miss Galt (Teacher) Traer, Iowa
Miss [Browy?] (nurse) Waterloo, Iowa 
Mr & Mrs Naj (banker) Wichita Kansas
Mrs McCarthy, chaperone
Miss Staddard, Butte teachers
Miss Almquist  Butte teachers
Rev Lodick - Mich 
Rev Hill - [P?]

Mr & Mrs Chaddock (farmer) Kansas
Mr P (clothier) Wichita, Kas
Mr Jones (Supt school) Salem O
Mr ________  Salem O
Mr Close  Spokane Wash
Mr & Mrs & two daughters & aunt Lizzie - South Bend Ind.
